text: @paulrbrown Not exactly a dashboard, but check out @marcua's twitInfo work from #CHI2011 for telling stories w/ twitter http://bit.ly/eFt5SX

@lintool @daniel_abadi What surprises me is that I think pre-tenures have the most to lose by going to this model. See:
http://bit.ly/lJLXrz
@marcua @daniel_abadi @samrmadden Although  the web already is the Bazaar!
@joe_hellerstein @divyagarwal I agree.  I think it is terrible we got rid of F2F PCs.  Jennifer showed it could work at SIGMOD 2005.
@joe_hellerstein @divyagrawal Renee Miller had meta-reviewers carefully look at all reviews @SIGMOD11 this year. I think it helped w/quality
@daniel_abadi  You inspired me to start a blog.... http://bit.ly/lDdt1s
@andy_pavlo BTW, despite there being no such thing as bad publicity, I'm sure not all those cites are rave reviews of the work. :)
@andy_pavlo By a long way.It has ~150 cites to 42 for the 2nd most cited.I cut the graph b/c I didnt want to further support Dan's point.:-)
@daniel_abadi Not sure if that proves my point or yours.  :)
@daniel_abadi In SIGMOD 2009, only 9/103 papers have 0 cites; median is 7. 4th most cited auth has no prior SIGMOD pubs http://bit.ly/lsOLI3
@daniel_abadi Absolutely true that maximizing paper count isn't required for tenure -- much more important to have a few high impact papers.
@daniel_abadi re: Accept everything, that will cause famous people to get all the attention.  For newcomers, paper acceptance=visibility.
